contents: The earth takes shape like clay under a seal;
its hills stand out like the folds of a garment.

contents.verseText: Light is withheld from the wicked, and their upraised arm is broken.
contents: Light is withheld from the wicked,
and their upraised arm is broken.

contents.verseText: Have you journeyed to the vents of the sea or walked in the trenches of the deep?
contents: Have you journeyed to the vents of the sea
or walked in the trenches of the deep?

contents.verseText: Have the gates of death been revealed to you? Have you seen the gates of the shadow of death?
contents: Have the gates of death been revealed to you?
Have you seen the gates of the shadow of death?

contents.verseText: Have you surveyed the extent of the earth? Tell Me, if you know all this.
contents: Have you surveyed the extent of the earth?
Tell Me, if you know all this.

contents.verseText: Where is the way to the home of light? Do you know where darkness resides,
contents: Where is the way to the home of light?
Do you know where darkness resides,

contents.verseText: so you can lead it back to its border? Do you know the paths to its home?
contents: so you can lead it back to its border?
Do you know the paths to its home?

contents.verseText: Surely you know, for you were already born! And the number of your days is great!
contents: Surely you know, for you were already born!
And the number of your days is great!

contents.verseText: Have you entered the storehouses of snow or observed the storehouses of hail,
contents: Have you entered the storehouses of snow
or observed the storehouses of hail,

contents.verseText: which I hold in reserve for times of trouble, for the day of war and battle?
contents: which I hold in reserve for times of trouble,
for the day of war and battle?

contents.verseText: In which direction is the lightning dispersed, or the east wind scattered over the earth?
contents: In which direction is the lightning dispersed,
or the east wind scattered over the earth?

contents.verseText: Who cuts a channel for the flood or clears a path for the thunderbolt,
contents: Who cuts a channel for the flood
or clears a path for the thunderbolt,

contents.verseText: to bring rain on a barren land, on a desert where no man lives,
contents: to bring rain on a barren land,
on a desert where no man lives,

contents.verseText: to satisfy the parched wasteland and make it sprout with tender grass?
contents: to satisfy the parched wasteland
and make it sprout with tender grass?

contents.verseText: Does the rain have a father? Who has begotten the drops of dew?
contents: Does the rain have a father?
Who has begotten the drops of dew?

contents.verseText: From whose womb does the ice emerge? Who gives birth to the frost from heaven,
contents: From whose womb does the ice emerge?
Who gives birth to the frost from heaven,

contents.verseText: when the waters become hard as stone and the surface of the deep is frozen?
contents: when the waters become hard as stone
and the surface of the deep is frozen?

contents.verseText: Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades or loosen the belt of Orion?
contents: Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades
or loosen the belt of Orion?

contents.verseText: Can you bring forth the constellations in their seasons or lead out the Bear and her cubs?
contents: Can you bring forth the constellations in their seasons

footnote.ft: Or bring forth Mazzaroth in its season

contents: or lead out the Bear
and her cubs?

contents.verseText: Do you know the laws of the heavens? Can you set their dominion over the earth?
contents: Do you know the laws of the heavens?
Can you set their dominion over the earth?

contents.verseText: Can you command the clouds so that a flood of water covers you?
contents: Can you command the clouds
so that a flood of water covers you?

contents.verseText: Can you send the lightning bolts on their way? Do they report to you, ‘Here we are’?
contents: Can you send the lightning bolts on their way?
Do they report to you, ‘Here we are’?

contents.verseText: Who has put wisdom in the heart or given understanding to the mind?
contents: Who has put wisdom in the heart

footnote.ft: Or Who has given the ibis wisdom, that is, wisdom about the flooding of the Nile

contents: or given understanding to the mind?

contents.verseText: Who has the wisdom to count the clouds? Or who can tilt the water jars of the heavens
contents: Who has the wisdom to count the clouds?
Or who can tilt the water jars of the heavens

contents.verseText: when the dust hardens into a mass and the clods of earth stick together?
contents: when the dust hardens into a mass
and the clods of earth stick together?

contents.verseText: Can you hunt the prey for a lioness or satisfy the hunger of young lions
contents: Can you hunt the prey for a lioness
or satisfy the hunger of young lions

contents.verseText: when they crouch in their dens and lie in wait in the thicket?
contents: when they crouch in their dens
and lie in wait in the thicket?

contents.verseText: Who provides food for the raven when its young cry out to God as they wander about for lack of food?
contents: Who provides food for the raven
when its young cry out to God
as they wander about for lack of food?

s1: The LORD Speaks of His Creation

contents.verseText: “Do you know when mountain goats give birth? Have you watched the doe bear her fawn?
contents: “Do you know when mountain goats give birth?
Have you watched the doe bear her fawn?

contents.verseText: Can you count the months they are pregnant? Do you know the time they give birth?
contents: Can you count the months they are pregnant?
Do you know the time they give birth?

contents.verseText: They crouch down and bring forth their young; they deliver their newborn.
contents: They crouch down and bring forth their young;
they deliver their newborn.

contents.verseText: Their young ones thrive and grow up in the open field; they leave and do not return.
contents: Their young ones thrive and grow up in the open field;
they leave and do not return.

contents.verseText: Who set the wild donkey free? Who released the swift donkey from the harness?
contents: Who set the wild donkey free?
Who released the swift donkey from the harness?

contents.verseText: I made the wilderness his home and the salt flats his dwelling.
contents: I made the wilderness his home
and the salt flats his dwelling.

contents.verseText: He scorns the tumult of the city and never hears the shouts of a driver.
contents: He scorns the tumult of the city
and never hears the shouts of a driver.

contents.verseText: He roams the mountains for pasture, searching for any green thing.
contents: He roams the mountains for pasture,
searching for any green thing.

contents.verseText: Will the wild ox consent to serve you? Will he stay by your manger at night?
contents: Will the wild ox consent to serve you?
Will he stay by your manger at night?

contents.verseText: Can you hold him to the furrow with a harness? Will he plow the valleys behind you?
contents: Can you hold him to the furrow with a harness?
Will he plow the valleys behind you?

contents.verseText: Can you rely on his great strength? Will you leave your hard work to him?
contents: Can you rely on his great strength?
Will you leave your hard work to him?

contents.verseText: Can you trust him to bring in your grain and gather it to your threshing floor?
contents: Can you trust him to bring in your grain
and gather it to your threshing floor?

contents.verseText: The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully, but cannot match the pinions and feathers of the stork.
contents: The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully,
but cannot match the pinions

footnote.ft: Pinions are the outer parts of a bird’s wings, including the flight feathers.

contents: and feathers of the stork.

contents.verseText: For she leaves her eggs on the ground and lets them warm in the sand.
contents: For she leaves her eggs on the ground
and lets them warm in the sand.

contents.verseText: She forgets that a foot may crush them, or a wild animal may trample them.
contents: She forgets that a foot may crush them,
or a wild animal may trample them.

contents.verseText: She treats her young harshly, as if not her own, with no concern that her labor was in vain.
contents: She treats her young harshly, as if not her own,
with no concern that her labor was in vain.

contents.verseText: For God has deprived her of wisdom; He has not endowed her with understanding.
contents: For God has deprived her of wisdom;
He has not endowed her with understanding.

contents.verseText: Yet when she proudly spreads her wings, she laughs at the horse and its rider.
contents: Yet when she proudly spreads her wings,
she laughs at the horse and its rider.

contents.verseText: Do you give strength to the horse or adorn his neck with a mane?
contents: Do you give strength to the horse
or adorn his neck with a mane?

contents.verseText: Do you make him leap like a locust, striking terror with his proud snorting?
contents: Do you make him leap like a locust,
striking terror with his proud snorting?

contents.verseText: He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength; he charges into battle.
contents: He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength;
he charges into battle.

contents.verseText: He laughs at fear, frightened of nothing; he does not turn back from the sword.
contents: He laughs at fear, frightened of nothing;
he does not turn back from the sword.

contents.verseText: A quiver rattles at his side, along with a flashing spear and lance.
contents: A quiver rattles at his side,
along with a flashing spear and lance.

contents.verseText: Trembling with excitement, he devours the distance; he cannot stand still when the ram’s horn sounds.
contents: Trembling with excitement, he devours the distance;
he cannot stand still when the ram’s horn sounds.

contents.verseText: At the blast of the horn, he snorts with fervor. He catches the scent of battle from afar—the shouts of captains and the cry of war.
contents: At the blast of the horn, he snorts with fervor.
He catches the scent of battle from afar—
the shouts of captains and the cry of war.

contents.verseText: Does the hawk take flight by your understanding and spread his wings toward the south?
contents: Does the hawk take flight by your understanding
and spread his wings toward the south?

contents.verseText: Does the eagle soar at your command and make his nest on high?
contents: Does the eagle soar at your command
and make his nest on high?

contents.verseText: He dwells on a cliff and lodges there; his stronghold is on a rocky crag.
contents: He dwells on a cliff and lodges there;
his stronghold is on a rocky crag.

contents.verseText: From there he spies out food; his eyes see it from afar.
contents: From there he spies out food;
his eyes see it from afar.

contents.verseText: His young ones feast on blood; and where the slain are, there he is.”
contents: His young ones feast on blood;
and where the slain are, there he is.”

s1: Job Humbles Himself before the LORD

contents.verseText: And the LORD said to Job:
contents: And the LORD said to Job:

contents.verseText: “Will the faultfinder contend with the Almighty? Let him who argues with God give an answer.”
contents: “Will the faultfinder contend with the Almighty?
Let him who argues with God give an answer.”

contents.verseText: Then Job answered the LORD:
contents: Then Job answered the LORD:

contents.verseText: “Behold, I am insignificant. How can I reply to You? I place my hand over my mouth.
contents: “Behold, I am insignificant. How can I reply to You?
I place my hand over my mouth.

contents.verseText: I have spoken once, but I have no answer—twice, but I have nothing to add.”
contents: I have spoken once, but I have no answer—
twice, but I have nothing to add.”

contents.verseText: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
contents: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:

contents.verseText: “Now brace yourself like a man; I will question you, and you shall inform Me.
contents: “Now brace yourself
like a man;
I will question you, and you shall inform Me.

contents.verseText: Would you really annul My justice? Would you condemn Me to justify yourself?
contents: Would you really annul My justice?
Would you condemn Me to justify yourself?

contents.verseText: Do you have an arm like God’s? Can you thunder with a voice like His?
contents: Do you have an arm like God’s?
Can you thunder with a voice like His?

contents.verseText: Then adorn yourself with majesty and splendor, and clothe yourself with honor and glory.
contents: Then adorn yourself with majesty and splendor,
and clothe yourself with honor and glory.

contents.verseText: Unleash the fury of your wrath; look on every proud man and bring him low.
contents: Unleash the fury of your wrath;
look on every proud man and bring him low.

contents.verseText: Look on every proud man and humble him; trample the wicked where they stand.
contents: Look on every proud man and humble him;
trample the wicked where they stand.

contents.verseText: Bury them together in the dust; imprison them in the grave.
contents: Bury them together in the dust;
imprison them in the grave.

contents.verseText: Then I will confess to you that your own right hand can save you.
contents: Then I will confess to you
that your own right hand can save you.

contents.verseText: Look at Behemoth, which I made along with you. He feeds on grass like an ox.
contents: Look at Behemoth, which I made along with you.
He feeds on grass like an ox.

contents.verseText: See the strength of his loins and the power in the muscles of his belly.
contents: See the strength of his loins
and the power in the muscles of his belly.

contents.verseText: His tail sways like a cedar; the sinews of his thighs are tightly knit.
contents: His tail sways like a cedar;
the sinews of his thighs are tightly knit.

contents.verseText: His bones are tubes of bronze; his limbs are rods of iron.
contents: His bones are tubes of bronze;
his limbs are rods of iron.

contents.verseText: He is the foremost of God’s works; only his Maker can draw the sword against him.
contents: He is the foremost of God’s works;
only his Maker can draw the sword against him.

contents.verseText: The hills yield him their produce, while all the beasts of the field play nearby.
contents: The hills yield him their produce,
while all the beasts of the field play nearby.

contents.verseText: He lies under the lotus plants, hidden among the reeds of the marsh.
contents: He lies under the lotus plants,

footnote.ft: Or bramble bushes; also in verse 22

contents: hidden among the reeds of the marsh.

contents.verseText: The lotus plants conceal him in their shade; the willows of the brook surround him.
contents: The lotus plants conceal him in their shade;
the willows
of the brook surround him.

contents.verseText: Though the river rages, Behemoth is unafraid; he remains secure, though the Jordan surges to his mouth.
contents: Though the river rages, Behemoth is unafraid;
he remains secure, though the Jordan surges to his mouth.

contents.verseText: Can anyone capture him as he looks on, or pierce his nose with a snare?
contents: Can anyone capture him as he looks on,
or pierce his nose with a snare?

s1: The LORD’s Power Shown in Leviathan

contents.verseText: “Can you pull in Leviathan with a hook or tie down his tongue with a rope?
contents: “Can you pull in Leviathan with a hook
or tie down his tongue with a rope?

contents.verseText: Can you put a cord through his nose or pierce his jaw with a hook?
contents: Can you put a cord through his nose
or pierce his jaw with a hook?

contents.verseText: Will he beg you for mercy or speak to you softly?
contents: Will he beg you for mercy
or speak to you softly?

contents.verseText: Will he make a covenant with you to take him as a slave for life?
contents: Will he make a covenant with you
to take him as a slave for life?

contents.verseText: Can you pet him like a bird or put him on a leash for your maidens?
contents: Can you pet him like a bird
or put him on a leash for your maidens?

contents.verseText: Will traders barter for him or divide him among the merchants?
contents: Will traders barter for him
or divide him among the merchants?

contents.verseText: Can you fill his hide with harpoons or his head with fishing spears?
contents: Can you fill his hide with harpoons
or his head with fishing spears?

contents.verseText: If you lay a hand on him, you will remember the battle and never repeat it!
contents: If you lay a hand on him,
you will remember the battle and never repeat it!

contents.verseText: Surely hope of overcoming him is false. Is not the sight of him overwhelming?
contents: Surely hope of overcoming him is false.
Is not the sight of him overwhelming?

contents.verseText: No one is so fierce as to rouse Leviathan. Then who is able to stand against Me?
contents: No one is so fierce as to rouse Leviathan.
Then who is able to stand against Me?

contents.verseText: Who has given to Me that I should repay him? Everything under heaven is Mine.
contents: Who has given to Me that I should repay him?
Everything under heaven is Mine.

contents.verseText: I cannot keep silent about his limbs, his power and graceful form.
contents: I cannot keep silent about his limbs,
his power and graceful form.

contents.verseText: Who can strip off his outer coat? Who can approach him with a bridle?
contents: Who can strip off his outer coat?
Who can approach him with a bridle?

footnote.ft: Or Who can come within his double mail?

contents.verseText: Who can open his jaws, ringed by his fearsome teeth?
contents: Who can open his jaws,
ringed by his fearsome teeth?

contents.verseText: His rows of scales are his pride, tightly sealed together.
contents: His rows of scales are his pride,
tightly sealed together.

contents.verseText: One scale is so near to another that no air can pass between them.
contents: One scale is so near to another
that no air can pass between them.

contents.verseText: They are joined to one another; they clasp and cannot be separated.
contents: They are joined to one another;
they clasp and cannot be separated.

contents.verseText: His snorting flashes with light, and his eyes are like the rays of dawn.
contents: His snorting flashes with light,
and his eyes are like the rays of dawn.

contents.verseText: Firebrands stream from his mouth; fiery sparks shoot forth!
contents: Firebrands stream from his mouth;
fiery sparks shoot forth!

contents.verseText: Smoke billows from his nostrils as from a boiling pot over burning reeds.
contents: Smoke billows from his nostrils
as from a boiling pot over burning reeds.

contents.verseText: His breath sets coals ablaze, and flames pour from his mouth.
contents: His breath sets coals ablaze,
and flames pour from his mouth.

contents.verseText: Strength resides in his neck, and dismay leaps before him.
contents: Strength resides in his neck,
and dismay leaps before him.

contents.verseText: The folds of his flesh are tightly joined; they are firm and immovable.
contents: The folds of his flesh are tightly joined;
they are firm and immovable.

contents.verseText: His chest is as hard as a rock, as hard as a lower millstone!
contents: His chest is as hard as a rock,
as hard as a lower millstone!

contents.verseText: When Leviathan rises up, the mighty are terrified; they withdraw before his thrashing.
contents: When Leviathan rises up, the mighty are terrified;
they withdraw before his thrashing.

contents.verseText: The sword that reaches him has no effect, nor does the spear or dart or arrow.
contents: The sword that reaches him has no effect,
nor does the spear or dart or arrow.

contents.verseText: He regards iron as straw and bronze as rotten wood.
contents: He regards iron as straw
and bronze as rotten wood.

contents.verseText: No arrow can make him flee; slingstones become like chaff to him.
contents: No arrow can make him flee;
slingstones become like chaff to him.

contents.verseText: A club is regarded as straw, and he laughs at the sound of the lance.
contents: A club is regarded as straw,
and he laughs at the sound of the lance.

contents.verseText: His undersides are jagged potsherds, spreading out the mud like a threshing sledge.
contents: His undersides are jagged potsherds,
spreading out the mud like a threshing sledge.

contents.verseText: He makes the depths seethe like a cauldron; he makes the sea like a jar of ointment.
contents: He makes the depths seethe like a cauldron;
he makes the sea like a jar of ointment.

contents.verseText: He leaves a glistening wake behind him; one would think the deep had white hair!
contents: He leaves a glistening wake behind him;
one would think the deep had white hair!

contents.verseText: Nothing on earth is his equal—a creature devoid of fear!
contents: Nothing on earth is his equal—
a creature devoid of fear!

contents.verseText: He looks down on all the haughty; he is king over all the proud.”
contents: He looks down on all the haughty;
he is king over all the proud.”

s1: Job Submits Himself to the LORD

contents.verseText: Then Job replied to the LORD:
contents: Then Job replied to the LORD:

contents.verseText: “I know that You can do all things and that no plan of Yours can be thwarted.
contents: “I know that You can do all things
and that no plan of Yours can be thwarted.

contents.verseText: You asked, ‘Who is this who conceals My counsel without knowledge?’ Surely I spoke of things I did not understand, things too wonderful for me to know.
contents: You asked, ‘Who is this
who conceals My counsel without knowledge?’
Surely I spoke of things I did not understand,
things too wonderful for me to know.

contents.verseText: You said, ‘Listen now, and I will speak. I will question you, and you shall inform Me.’
contents: You said, ‘Listen now, and I will speak.
I will question you, and you shall inform Me.’

contents.verseText: My ears had heard of You, but now my eyes have seen You.
contents: My ears had heard of You,
but now my eyes have seen You.

contents.verseText: Therefore I retract my words, and I repent in dust and ashes.”
contents: Therefore I retract my words,
and I repent in dust and ashes.”

contents.verseText: After the LORD had spoken these words to Job, He said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My wrath is kindled against you and your two friends. For you have not spoken about Me accurately, as My servant Job has.
contents: After the LORD had spoken these words to Job, He said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My wrath is kindled against you and your two friends. For you have not spoken about Me accurately, as My servant Job has.

contents.verseText: So now, take seven bulls and seven rams, go to My servant Job, and sacrifice a burnt offering for yourselves. Then My servant Job will pray for you, for I will accept his prayer and not deal with you according to your folly. For you have not spoken accurately about Me, as My servant Job has.”
contents: So now, take seven bulls and seven rams, go to My servant Job, and sacrifice a burnt offering for yourselves. Then My servant Job will pray for you, for I will accept his prayer and not deal with you according to your folly. For you have not spoken accurately about Me, as My servant Job has.”

contents.verseText: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the LORD had told them; and the LORD accepted Job’s request.
contents: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the LORD had told them; and the LORD accepted Job’s request.

contents.verseText: After Job had prayed for his friends, the LORD restored his prosperity and doubled his former possessions.
contents: After Job had prayed for his friends, the LORD restored his prosperity and doubled his former possessions.

contents.verseText: All his brothers and sisters and prior acquaintances came and dined with him in his house. They consoled him and comforted him over all the adversity that the LORD had brought upon him. And each one gave him a piece of silver and a gold ring.
contents: All his brothers and sisters and prior acquaintances came and dined with him in his house. They consoled him and comforted him over all the adversity that the LORD had brought upon him. And each one gave him a piece of silver

footnote.ft: Hebrew a kesitah; the value or weight of the kesitah is no longer known.

contents: and a gold ring.

contents.verseText: So the LORD blessed Job’s latter days more than his first. He owned 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, and 1,000 female donkeys.
contents: So the LORD blessed Job’s latter days more than his first. He owned 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, and 1,000 female donkeys.

contents.verseText: And he also had seven sons and three daughters.
contents: And he also had seven sons and three daughters.

contents.verseText: He named his first daughter Jemimah, his second Keziah, and his third Keren-happuch.
contents: He named his first daughter Jemimah, his second Keziah, and his third Keren-happuch.

contents.verseText: No women as beautiful as Job’s daughters could be found in all the land, and their father granted them an inheritance among their brothers.
contents: No women as beautiful as Job’s daughters could be found in all the land, and their father granted them an inheritance among their brothers.

contents.verseText: After this, Job lived 140 years and saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.
contents: After this, Job lived 140 years and saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.

contents.verseText: And so Job died, old and full of years.
contents: And so Job died, old and full of years.
